Quick Side Note: Lots of people have questioned how difficult it would be for torpedoes to sink a carrier but many don't seem to realize just how utterly powerful even a single modern torpedo is. While WW2 era torpedoes normally took several to sink large capital ships, advancement in explosives and propulsion systems have made modern torpedoes unimaginably powerful. While a ship such as a modern carrier has a large assortment of bulkheads and water tight compartments in the event of a hull breach, the sheer explosive power of even a single torpedo is immense and can cause so much pressure and warping of the hulls of ships that it literally "breaks the back" of ships such as destroyers or cruisers. While it might not ultimately sink the carrier, even as few as 2 or 3 would be enough to kill a vast number of personnel which could render retaliation, rescue, and light repair work near impossible.

For the problem at the end, the doors must both be safe.  If the door with the sign is deadly, then there is no way of knowing if the sign is true or false. If the door with the sign is safe and the other is deadly, then the sign is true. The only way the sign can be false is if both are safe. Interesting puzzle.
if this door is safe , the other door is deadly x = this door is safe y = the other door is deadly ~ = not if x then y ~(X-->y) ~(~x V y ) (~~x A y) (x A y) the door with the sign is the safe door
The door question is easy. If the sign on the door is false. We know nothing about the doors. We don't know if either is safe or deadly, because the sign is bullshit.
The false statements is that the second door is deadly? So both doors are safe? Hey, people with 750 gmat score, tell me.

If A then B. If A is false, the statement is vacuously true. If A and B are true, the statement is True. For the statement to be False: A = T, B = F. In other words A is Safe, B is Safe. Both doors are safe.

The answer is â€œThe first door is deadly, the second door is safe.â€ The key word in this puzzle is â€œeither.â€ They cannot both be deadly or safe. If one is deadly, the other must be safe. And since we know the sign is false the only other answer is the opposite of the sign.

This is a Discrete Math problem.   This is a conditional proposition with the propositions 'p' and 'q' that are constituents of the conditional 'p -> q' which means 'p' implies 'q' or if 'p', then 'q'. We can see from the problem that 'p' is the proposition 'this door is safe' and that 'q' is the proposition 'the other door is deadly'. 'p -> q' is the condition in its entirety, 'if this door is safe, the other door is deadly'. The truth table for this logic is as follows. T - True, F - False.  p     |     q     |     p -> q T           TÂ              T T           F              F F           TÂ              T F           F              T  Since the sign is represented by 'p -> q' and it is false, we know that it is only false when p is true and q is false.  When 'p' is true the proposition 'this door is safe' is true.  When 'q' is false the proposition 'the other door is deadly' is false, meaning 'the other door is safe'.  Therefore both doors are safe is the answer.
3:42 MAAL

A: door A is safe. B: door B is safe.  "If this door is safe, then the other is deadly" <=> (A => !B) <=> (!A or !B) (using the fact that (X => Y) <=> (!X or Y))  "The sign is false" <=> !( !A or !B ) Apply De Morgan's law to get: A and B.  Both doors are safe.

Brilliant puzzle answer: both doors are safe. Explanation:  Let p be the proposition that door 1 is SAFE; Let q be the proposition that door 2 is SAFE; Thus ~q represents that door 2 is deadly;  the implication is: if door 1 is safe, the other door is deadly.  in logic this is p => ~q.   The truth table for the above implication is shown below:  p      q     ~q     p=> ~q T      T       F          F T      F       T          T F      T       F          T F      F       T          T  The implication is only false when BOTH propositions p and q are true (T). Thus for the implication to be false, we can infer that both doors must safe.

It would just mean, that information about A's safety no longer gives us any information about B's safety. But actual information about any door's safety isn't given at any point. Â @SchaaschaaÂ  I came to the same conclusion, that even if we assume that door 1 being "false" means that it's deadly, it doesn't give us any information about the state of door 2. But even assuming that "false = deadly" is a leap of logic.

Â @SchaaschaaÂ  The reason why A is known to be safe is because of when an implication is false. If an implication is false (in this case what is written on the sign), then the first part of the implication is true (the IF part) and the second part of the implication is false ( the THEN part). This leads to the first door being safe and the second door to NOT be deadly, therefore being safe.

Â @dondonnysson4973Â  I think the problem suffers from poor wording. What you just wrote, isn't the consequence of the IMPLICATION being false, it's the implication of us KNOWING the implication to be false. It's like saying "If there is a McDonalds in London, then there is none in Berlin" is false. That doesn't mean that there has to be a McDonalds in both places; it is just that the only way of KNOWING the statement to be false is to know such a place in both cities. Juan Carlos isn't a carrier, it's an LHD with fixed wing capability. For starters LHD's have a different primary mission to Aircraft carriers, for second if you want to count LHD's you need a huge amount of other ships on this list; the Australian LHD's, the Mistrals, HMS Ocean (or atlantico or whatever it's called now), the American LHD's, the Japanese Helicopter Destroyers, the list goes on and on.

Â @dernwineÂ  it's still a carrier, and many also count the American LHDs as carriers precisely for their Harriers, the video even says that's the main characteristic of a carrier.  And even if we where to apply that logic, then the second italian carrier should be off the list.

Â @EAMR262Â  No... it's not a carrier, it's an Amphibious assault ship. It's a different class of vessel, with a different purpose. The Cavor (or Garibaldi difficutl to guess what you mean by second) are both dedicated Fleet Aircraft Carriers (albeit small ones).  The fact is that size isn't the primary differentiation between LHD's and Carriers, but what they are intended for. So LHD's like Juan Carlos compromise their ability to operate as a true carrier and instead are a sort of hybrid Carrier-Troop Transport-Landing Craft thing. Yes they can carry VSTOL aircraft, yes they may even carry more VSTOL aircraft than a Fleet carrier, however their main role is to carry and support troops from the sea on to a beach. Hence Cavour, Ocean, Mistral, Wasps, etc are not Carriers. They are Amphibious Assault ships. It's a different classification.
dernwine harrier is vertical takeoff

dernwine meaning itâ€™s a helo Carrier that vstols can operate from. Itâ€™s not a true fixed-wing carrier.

Â @stoutyyyyÂ   no... a Fleet Carrier can operate only VSTOL aircraft as well. You're talking about the difference between CATOBAR (Catapult Assisted Take Off, Barrier Arrested Recovery) , STOBAR (Short Take Off Barrier Arrested Recovery) and STOVL (Short Take Off Vertical Landing) aircraft carriers. Plenty of Fleet carriers are STOBAR or STOVL.   The reason Juan Carlos is not a "Carrier" is because it's designed to launch troops onto a beachhead. This is also why the American LHD's aren't considered Carriers, nothing to do with their Airwing so much as their designed role is assaulting a coast line with troops.

quick thing to note, i wouldn't take those two wargames as sign of a fundamental shift in the effectiveness of aircraft carriers. those games were both conducted under specifics conditions in an enclosed area; the keystone of aircraft carrier strategy is stealth and distance which are both incompatible with that scenario. under actual combat conditions it's unlikely that the enemy would even know that there was a US carrier around let alone be able to get a submarine anywhere near it without the submarine being found out first. take for example 83's FLEETEX games. the US distracted the Soviets with one carrier while they used a different carrier to carry out secret operations to the complete obliviousness of the USSR. it was only later on when they purposely tried exposing themselves that the Soviets found out what had been happening. so unless an enemy develops enough to beat US stealth AND radar technology, both of which the US is DECADES ahead in, then US carriers will still be safe to roam the oceans.

Let's break the sign into two parts: p = "This door is safe" q = "Other door is deadly"  so we have: if "p", then "q", which we can translate to: p -> q  Since we are given that the sign is is false, there is only 1 possibility that it could happen: when "p" is true and "q" is false.  Therefor, we have that "The door is safe" is True, and "Other door is deadly" is false, which means both doors are safe.

"If this door(A) is safe, the other door(B) is deadly" is FALSE.  So: If A is safe, then B cannot be deadly(that's the original false statement);so B must be safe. If B is safe, then A cannot be deadly(contrapositive of the original false statement is also false); A must be safe.  Therefore: Both doors are safe

For the Brilliant question: Both doors are safe. For a not very cohesive technical explanation, the sign is an If X then Y, so if X = Safe, then Y = Deadly. Therefore, if A is Safe,  then B is deadly. If A ISN'T Safe, then we have NO IDEA what B is. B could be either safe or deadly. However, the question is based on the premise being false. So, if A isn't safe, then B could be safe or deadly and the premise is true. If A IS safe, the only way the premise could be false is if B is ALSO safe. It took some mental wrestling to get to that answer and I had a whole class on logic like this a few years ago.

For the Door-thingy - that is a really badly worded riddle.  Spoilers for those that want to try it.    . . . Too late now  "If the sign is false" - the sign says that if door A is safe then door B is deadly - now if the sign is false this means they could both be deadly, they could both be safe, or just one of them is deadly and the other is safe. We are only told that the sign saying "If A then not B" is not true - with the problem that the sign does not make a statement about the doors but a statement about the rules to the door. This is however not a negation if the rule nor does it invalidate that outcome - the way it is presented it only tells us that we do not know what door B is when A is safe - so we know we do know nothing about the situation. Of course you could interpret the quiz a bit differently as in the doors never follow that rule. in that case if A is safe then B is safe, if a is deadly then B can be anything.  With the first interpretation we know absolutely nothing, with the second we can only rule out 1 of 4 scenarios - in both cases none of the answers are correct.

If 1 is safe and 2 is deadly => the sign is obviously true. If 1 is safe and 2 is safe (not deadly) => the sign is false (violated / contradicted). If 1 is deadly => the sign is true, because it cannot be contradicted. If we cannot contradict it, it has to be true. The only time the sign is false (contradicted) is when 1 is safe and 2 is safe (not deadly). Final answer, both doors are safe, that's the only way to violate the sign. I know it's tricky, because the sign doesn't say anything about the case when 1 is deadly. However, we cannot contradict or disprove something that we don't know about! This is how logical implication works in Boolean algebra. Innocent until proven wrong. Â @David-qs7yvÂ  An indicative conditional need not be true if the antecedent is false. Same goes for a counterfactual conditional. In other words, the falsity of an indicative (or counterfactual) conditional doesn't imply that its antecedent is true. Hence, the possibility that the left door is deadly is still open. (In fact, we see by contraposition of the conditional that this can only be the case if simultaneously the right door is deadly; i.e. iff both doors are deadly.)  By contrast, a material conditional is true whenever its antecedent is false. In other words, the falsity of the conditional implies that the antecedent is true: in this case, that the left door is safe. (The falsity of the conditional furthermore implies that the is can only be the case if simultaneously the right door is safe.)

Boolean algebra is not programming. It's not IF THEN ELSE. In programming, you can skip an entire program line, you can have undefined behavior. That's not possible in Boolean algebra. You can only have TRUE or FALSE, nothing else. Even an IF condition has a perfectly defined behavior, either TRUE or FALSE. The truth table for an inductive conditional is such: p    q    p->q T    T    T (because if p then q is not violated) T    F    F (because if p then q is violated) F    T    T (because if p then q is not violated) F    F    T (because if p then q is not violated) There's no undefined behavior in Boolean logic, even a condition is always 100% defined. Again, this is not a program code that may or may not be conditionally executed.

Logical induction works a bit like Sudoku. If you can prove that a certain number cannot be present in a square, then you rule it out (FALSE). Otherwise the number can potentially be present (TRUE). Everything is TRUE unless you find a contradiction, in which case it's FALSE. So even the unknown state is considered TRUE, until you completely rule it out. It's like air crash investigation. Until you rule out a possible cause (FALSE), it remains in consideration (TRUE). Same in detective work.

Yes, afaik, philosophers' dissatisfaction with the material conditional was also a main driver behind the development of modal logic. Modal logic formalizes the idea of 'strict implication', where A strictly implies B iff, necessarily, A materially implies B. That notion of strict implication is often much closer to our intuitive conception of implication. For example, it's not the case that the fact that I'm eating chocolate strictly implies that the Earth is round, since (the thought is) there is a possible world where I eat chocolate and the Earth is flat.

So for the question at the end, the answer would be "Both doors are safe". Here's my explanation:  Let's denote safe by "S" and deadly by "D". Then the two doors can be SS, SD, DS or DD. For SS, the sign is false since the door 1 is safe but the door 2 is not deadly ( = safe). For SD, the sign is clearly true since the door 1 is safe and the door 2 is deadly. For both DS and DD, the sign is true because the antecedent ("the door 1 is safe") is false. (See: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Material_conditional ) So the sign is false if and only if both doors are safe.

One word "initiative."  The principal advantage of a carrier is it's stand off range.  It gives the US Navy a lot more options in a fight where the enemy is going to have to be on the defensive. The side with the carrier can dictate the pace of a fight assuming it's a fight between two relatively equal surface fleets.  The carrier side can see further, so it can detect the enemy sooner, and strike faster.  Usually the side that attacks first in a battle wins because the other side is forced to be reactive instead of proactive.  On the other hand the Carrier has weaknesses but the fact is that enemy vessels are just as weak to those same threats.  That and those exercises with the Swedes and the French were just that, exercises, the fact that the U.S. Navy is learning on a regular basis is a good thing for them if anything.  That and those exercises test very particular scenarios so in a real world situation things might be different, but that obviously cuts both ways. The concept this question is testing if you can negate a logical implication and use a truth table.  p: door 1 is safe q: door 2 is deadly  We can apply logical equivalency rules. Original statement: p -> q Equivalent statement: Â¬pâˆ¨q  The question wants use to assume the EQUIVALENT STATEMENT is FALSE. Negation of equivalent statement: pâˆ§Â¬q  The question asks, assuming the NEGATION is TRUE, what must be the state of each door? If you make a truth table, then  pâˆ§Â¬q is ONLY true when p is true and q is false.  p: door 1 is safe q: door 2 is deadly q false: door 2 is safe  Hence both doors must be safe.  I realize that this is not an intuitive explanation at all. If you haven't learned formal logic this probably looks like a bunch of shenanigans to you. Just wanted to give a clear outline of the problem solving process and indirectly imply that the question was written correctly.  There's a better way to explain this with only words, but I fell back on logic when my words failed.

You didn't cover the real reason aircraft carriers are so powerful: horizons.   Imagine the quintessential battleship. Big guns with long range. The problem is that those guns can't be aimed further than the horizon, which is about 15 miles at the top of the bridge. The initial solution to this is to have catapult launched seaplanes equipped with radios ti be the eyes of the ship. Carriers simply moved this role off the battleships at first. However, battleships ran into another problem: it's guns had limited range. Once this limit was reached, the carrier found its time to shine. Aircraft could carry ordinance well beyond visible range. This provided two immense advantages. 1: the carrier would be beyond visible sight of their targets, making them safer when attacking. 2 they could control vast swaths of the ocean using aircraft.   The problem with countering carriers with submarines is that submarines are generally slower than aircraft carriers, so even if carriers can't detect subs, they can simply outpace them.

Â @Snailman3516Â  It doesn't work that way. Subs have always been slower than surface ships, at least when they are submerged. The idea is that subs position themselves along the anticipated course of their targets, convoys etc so as to force the targets to take wider courses to avoid the subs. This causes the target to expend more fuel and take longer to reach their destination. Not to mention they can also position themselves off the ports and attack their targets as they come in and out. If U-Boats could find convoys in the vast Atlantic with not much more than using binoculars I'm sure they would have no problem finding targets today with all the modern detection equipment available to them. I would also point out that subs are far more effective against convoys than picking off individual military ships. They really only attack military ships if they are sitting ducks moving slowly of stopped. Then the odds are in their favour.

I think your initial assumption is incorrect. You can have door 1 be unsafe and the statement  "if door 1 is safe then door 2 is deadly" be true since a false hypothesis can imply a true conclusion. All you are able to conclude if the statement is true is that there must exist some door that is unsafe (if door 1 is safe then the statement implies door 2 is dangerous, if door 1 is dangerous then door 2 could be dangerous or safe).  The fact that the statement is false, however, tells us more information about the state of the doors. First, suppose that door 1 is dangerous. Then the statement "if door 1 is safe then door 2 is dangerous" is vacuously true, contradicting the assumption that the implication is false. Therefore, door 1 is safe. However, since door 1 is safe and the statement "if door 1 is safe then door 2 is dangerous" is false this would imply that door 2 is also dangerous. Therefore both doors are safe.

"If this door is safe, the other is deadly."   Since this is a hypothetical and the first part does not actually claim the first door is safe, the only thing that could be viewed as a true-false statement is what happens when door one is safe. If it is false to say that door 2 is deadly when door 1 is safe, the only truth you can know is that IF door 1 is safe, then door 2 is also safe.  You don't learn any information about the current state of the doors; just what you can conclude were you to be given more information. All that said, I don't think the question provides an appropriate answer from among the four it suggests.
Nope. Both are safe. For that statement to be false, the door would have to be safe while the other would have to be not deadly.  Under any other situation, the statement itself isn't rendered false.

The first part of the sign's statement is a conditional, not a separate statement.  The answer is the grayed out option: "Nothing is learned about door B".   We're not given any information about what is behind the doors, so a conditional statement carries absolutely no logical weight.  The only thing we learn about door B is conditional that IF door A is safe, then door B is not deadly (and therefore safe as that is the only other option).  We learn conditional information, not anything else.
Â @thekwoka4707Â    I feel like there's some logic problem convention being used here that doesn't track with reality outside of these problems.

Not quite. If the sign says "if this door is safe, then the other door is deadly" and this door was deadly, then the other door doesn't matter, the sign is still true. So if this door is deadly, but the other is safe, the sign didn't lie. It said the other door was deadly IF this door was safe. Since this door wasn't safe, it didn't lie. The ONLY scenario that makes the sign false is if the antecedent is true (this door is safe) but the consequence is false (which is when the other door is safe). So, if the sign is false, both doors are safe. If you've ever taken a logic class, you can see it below.  p = this door is safe q = the other door is safe. Sign: p -> -q Sign is false: -(p -> -q) -(-p v -q) def. Of conditional p ^ q De'M P and Q.

Â @GlacialScionÂ  Logic follows reality. Think about it this way. If I say "If you do a flip, I'll give you a dollar". If you do a flip and I give you a dollar, I'm telling the truth. If you do a flip and I don't give you a dollar, I'm a liar. But if you don't do a flip, it doesn't matter if I give you a dollar or not, because the first part of the conditional was false. I could say "I'll give you a dollar for trying". I wouldn't have lied, because my statement of "If A Then B" Doesn't take into account when A is false. The only time I am a liar is if A is true (you did a flip) and B is false (I don't pay you a dollar). Now let's look back at the sign. The only situation in which the sign is false is when the first part is true (this door is safe) and the other part is false (the other door is safe). So if the sign is false, both doors are safe.

Â @thatunnamedredshirtÂ    In reality, there was no indication in the problem that the current state of the doors disproves the sign. It's merely stated that the sign is false. Were the question phrased "You open the doors and discover the sign to be false", I don't think there would be any confusion, but it's unclear as it stands, which is why I think there's some logic problem convention being used to ignore the inconsistency in setup.

Â @GlacialScionÂ  we're not asking what happens when you open the door and discover something. We're asking what would be true if the sign was false. If the sign is false, both doors are safe. Anything other than both doors being safe wouldn't make the sign false.

Â @thatunnamedredshirtÂ    Knowing that IF the first door is safe, the second door is safe does not tell you anything about the state of the first door. Both doors can be deadly and the conditional statement "If Door A is safe, Door B is safe" still be true, because nothing about the problem indicates the current state of the doors is responsible for the original statement being false.

Â @GlacialScionÂ  The conclusion isn't a condition. We know one thing for certain. That is, the sign on the door reads "IF this door is safe, THEN the other door is deadly".  Next, we assume that the sign is false. That's when we say "IF the sign is false, THEN we know both doors are safe." If this door is deadly, then the sign isn't false, because the sign didn't discuss that case. The sign only said "IF this door is safe...". If it isn't safe, the sign isn't false. So the only scenario we have to worry about is when the door IS safe. So what can we do to make it false? If this door is safe, and the second door is deadly, the sign isn't false. If this door is safe, and the other door is safe, THIS is the ONLY situation in which the sign is false.  Now, back to the original statement. If the sign is false, then what do we know? Well, there is only one situation in which the sign in false, and that's when both doors are safe. So, in conclusion "IF the sign is false, THEN both doors are safe"

Â @kerrykennedy6398Â  No it's not. This answer is correct. It is not denial of antecedent because he did not negate an implication. He used the definition of implies. P implies Q is defined as NOT P OR Q.   For the challenge P = door 1 is safe, Q = door 2 is unsafe. The sign says: door 1 safe implies door 2 unsafe (P implies Q). This is the same as: door 1 unsafe OR door 2 unsafe (NOT P OR Q)  The sign is false: NOT (door 1 safe implies door 2 unsafe).    (NOT (P implies Q)) Using the definition of implies: (NOT ( NOT P OR Q )). Distributing the NOT: ( NOT NOT P AND NOT Q). NOT NOT cancels: ( P AND NOT Q )  Which means: door 1 is safe and not (door 2 is unsafe) Which means: door 1 is safe and door 2 is safe.

On a modern US Carrier, the superstructure, known as the "island," has about 6 decks that view the flight deck: The lowest one, which is at flight deck level, is where the movement officer is stationed, who is responsible for coordinating aircraft movement on the flight deck. Two levels above that, is an enclosed platform where a camera is mounted that gives a panoramic view of the flight deck, and is used for supervising and recording all aircraft operations. Directly above that is the Flag Bridge, then the actual Bridge, and at the top of the superstructure is the Control tower, who coordinates launching and recovering aircraft.

Also, an aircraft carrier is mostly an offensive weapon (for defense it's much cheaper and simpler to operate land airbase), many countries' military are geared mainly for defense rather than offensive capabilities.  Aircraft carriers can bring some strategical and tactical advantages, but overall the planes they carry have to be designed for the short take off, landing, and compacted storage in the carrier. Â robert leonardÂ  You misspelled "Mach", unless you mean to say the missile does nothing but mock the ships it's fired at.  Besides, the US has missiles capable of shooting it down, like the RIM-162 ESSM.  And if you want raw speed, look no further than the RIM-161 anti satellite and ballistic missile, some variants are capable of mach 15.

Â robert leonardÂ  I highly doubt that there's anything the US lacks the guidance systems to shoot down.  The aforementioned mach 15 capable RIM-161 has successfully shot down a low earth orbit satellite, something that usually travels around mach 22.  Another thing to note was that it had to be a direct hit, the RIM-161 carries no explosive warhead, just a kinetic slug travelling at speeds fast enough to vaporize just about anything on impact.   A comparatively slower mach 5-6 capable Zircon, the Russian hyper sonic missile in question, should be child's play.  Even if you were using a slower interceptor missile actually designed to kill other missiles, such as the RIM-162 ESSM, which is capable of mach 4, I suspect that it would still be able to hit and kill a maneuvering hyper sonic object, even if slower.    In addition, the RIM-162 in combination with the Vertical Launch System can and will be spam fired, meaning there will be MANY missiles on their way to intercept the Zircon, and chances are at least one will hit, which is all you need.   You've gotta remember that the Aegis system is capable of locking on to such things as well, as it is capable of locking onto and killing ballistic missiles in their terminal (final fall) phase, which would in theory be cloaked in the same plasma cloud that makes the Zircon supposedly incapable of being locked on to.  This also means ballistic missiles mimic common Russian anti ship missile strategy, fly high and fast, then dive on targets at insane speeds, though ballistic missiles tend to fall a lot faster.  The problem here is that Aegis equipped ships have already proven themselves capable of intercepting such threats with both 162's and 161's.
